Dear Dave,

Thanks very much. Your FlowReactor class is going to be very us=
eful.
Any chance that future releases of FlowReactor might include surface
=
chemistry as well?

I took a look at the ignite.m matlab function and think=
 I should be
able to do something similar in Python using the functions fro=
m the
Kinetics class (Unfortunately, I don't have access to Matlab). I have=

an f2py'd version of vode that I can use to do the integration. Thanks
aga=
in.

Best,
Paul

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c.=
..> wrote:
>
> Paul,
> 
> Currently using the Cantera Reactor class this is=
 hard to do.  It 
> allows you to fix T, or solve the energy equation, but =
it doesn't allow 
> specified T(time), or P(time).
> 
> For now, probably t=
he best thing to do is to write the ODEs yourself, 
> and use Cantera to ev=
aluate the terms in the equations. See, for 
> example, the Cantera MATLAB =
demos "ignite.m", "ignite2.m", and the 
> function in the Cantera toolbox "=
reactor_ode.m" for an example of this 
> approach. The MATLAB stiff ODE int=
egrator used in these demos works 
> fine for these problems.
> 
> I have a=
ctually written a new class "FlowReactor" that is closer to 
> what you wan=
t, but it is not ready for release yet.   It is designed to 
> simulate rea=
cting plug flow in a channel, and includes compressibility 
> effects, heat=
 loss, friction, etc.  I'll make sure to allow specified 
> T(x) and P(x) a=
s an option.  I don't know precisely when this will be 
> ready for release=
 - maybe in a couple of weeks.
> 
> Dave
> 
> 
> On Nov 8, 2005, at 8:04 AM=
, peyelvington wrote:
> 
> > Dear Group,
> >
> > I would like to simulate a=
 zero-d, variable-T,P reactor. I have
> > profiles of T(time) and P(time) f=
rom a separate fluid-dynamic
> > calculation of flow in a probe and sample =
line. I'm assuming plug flow
> > and so using the zero-d eqns with time in =
the batch system really
> > representing residence time along the PFR (i.e.=
 sample line). (I'm
> > trying to predict measurement errors due to chemica=
l conversion in
> > sample systems used to measure trace gases from jet air=
craft engines.)
> > I have a table of values for time, T and P that I would=
 like to
> > interpolate to get the current reactor conditions.
> >
> > Doe=
s anyone have a Python script to model a variable-T,P reactor or
> > some g=
eneral guidance about how to approach the problem? Thanks very
> > much for=
 your help.
> >
> > I'm using the Python interface to Cantera v1.6.
> >
> >=
 Best,
> >
> > Paul
